channel.title: Compendia on opt-models
channel.description: Recent content in Compendia on opt-models

item.title: Welcome to the Optimization Impostors' Compendium
item.description: Introducing the Compendium, its intended audience, its two main focuses - a code-first approach to building optimization models and increasing the speed of optimization computation - me (Martin Laskowski) and my motivations for creating this resource.

item.title: What's inside...
item.description: An overview of the contents and the release structure of the Optimization Impostors’ Compendium.

item.title: Talk on Maven
item.description: Discuss the topics covered here on Maven: a social media platform structured around an “interest graph” rather than a “friend/social graph”. Maven feels good to me, like a glimpse of a possible shift in online culture from our current limbic-system hacking reality to something healthier and promoting of genuine serendipity.

item.title: The magical nature of Optimization Programming
item.description: Optimization programming is an extremely declarative paradigm which is beyond fantastic and also exactly why many newcomers get into trouble.

item.title: Optimization Toolchain: Major Component Overview
item.description: An overview of the modern optimization toolchain typically deployed in commercial applications: data sources, glue languages, modeling langs/tools, solvers and optional user interfaces.

item.title: Optimization Toolchain: Model + Solver
item.description: A close look at large-scale optimization modeling tools and languages, and linear and nonlinear solvers.

item.title: Optimization Toolchain: Data Sources
item.description: Discussing common data sources for optimization models and their various means of connection to the model.

item.title: Optimization Toolchain: User Interfaces
item.description: A look at practical as well as fancy means by which humans can interact with optimization models during development and in production.

item.title: Optimization Toolchain: 'Glue' Languages
item.description: Discussing the use and interchangeability of general languages which ‘glue’ optimization application components together and implement out-of-model app logic.

item.title: The five parts of an Optimization Model
item.description: An unpacking of the five major components of an optimization model: SETS, parameters, Variables, Objective and Constraints.

item.title: Dev Creature Comforts
item.description: Extolling the value of tools like Git, fast code/text editors, exploratory data analysis (EDA) tools like GraphXR, whiteboarding tools like Whimsical, containerization, model/data separation and friendly syntax and naming conventions.

item.title: Practical Opt Theory: Descriptive, Predictive, Prescriptive ... analytics
item.description: My perspective on where and why mathematical optimization methods are commonly implemented in the commercial wild, sometimes as the Prescriptive component following earlier Predictive and/or Descriptive components in a modern Data Science pipeline.

item.title: Practical Opt Theory: Optimization Problem Types
item.description: A whirlwind tour through the main problem types in the field of Combinatorial Optimization with an emphasis on their various real-world commercial implementations.

item.title: Practical Opt Theory: Optimization Problem Hardness
item.description: Discussing the attributes of an optimization problem which make it harder to solve: combinatorial explosions, a lack of exploitable graph or other structure, etc. Also, a look at the usefulness of concepts like NP-hardness and Big O in addressing optimization problem hardness.

item.title: Practical Opt Theory: Optimization Methods
item.description: A look at various optimization methods such as Stochastic data perturbation, dynamic solving, multi-objective optimization, pattern generation, heuristic and Metaheuristic solvers, and more.

item.title: Practical Opt Theory: The Myth of the Objective
item.description: An invitation to consider the application of mathematical optimization in light of the view expressed by Kenneth O. Stanley and Joel Lehman in their book ‘Why Greatness Cannot Be Planned’ (2015). I posit that a richness of possible solutions can in many use cases be more valuable than a closer-to-optimum objective value.

item.title: Speeding Opt Apps
item.description: A methodical walk across the optimization toolchain and down through the underlying stack/OS in search of performance bottlenecks and their remedies.

item.title: Predictions: Opt Tools, Skills and Apps beyond 2024
item.description: My perspective on the markets for optimization products, services and skills in 2024 and beyond. I address developers, students, tool buyers and vendors in light of the current AI explosion.

item.title: Optimization â¤ï¸ AI
item.description: A show-and-tell discussion of generative AI’s current value in writing optimization models, data integrations, tests, UIs. Also some discussion about readability of natural vs AML language for humans.

item.title: Thank you to...
item.description: Thanks to the folks without whom this would not happen: Seth Godin, Steve Walters, The Black Crowes, Martha Wells and Murderbot, Techno Tim, Christian Lempa, Veronica Explains, Lawrence Systems, Jeff Delaney and Fireship.io, Nuno CoraÃ§Ã£o and Blowfish, the Rebrickable Team, Rebecca and you.

item.title: Hey, Community!
item.description: A call to the optimization community to build valuable resources together: models and integrations, open source solvers, a pro-bono project marketplace, tool-agnostic discussion forum(s).
